summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The FreeEventParams method frees resources associated with the parameters of an event.

member.name: IMediaEventEx.GetEvent

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The GetEvent method retrieves the next event notification from the event queue.

member.param: Pointer to a variable that receives the event code.
Pointer to a variable that receives the first event parameter.
Pointer to a variable that receives the second event parameter.
Time-out interval, in milliseconds. Use INFINITE to block until there is an event.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include those shown in the following table.

member.name: IMediaEventEx.GetNotifyFlags

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The GetNotifyFlags method determines whether event notifications are enabled.

param.name: lplNoNotifyFlags
param.para: Pointer to a variable that receives one of the following values:

member.returns: Returns S_OK if successful, or E_POINTER if the lplNoNotifyFlags parameter is NULL.

member.name: IMediaEventEx.SetNotifyFlags

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The SetNotifyFlags method enables or disables event notifications.

param.name: lNoNotifyFlags
param.para: Value indicating whether to enable or disable event notifications. Must be one of the following values:

member.returns: Returns S_OK if successful, or E_INVALIDARG if the lNoNotifyFlags parameter is invalid.

member.name: IMediaEventEx.SetNotifyWindow

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The SetNotifyWindow method registers a window to process event notifications.

member.param: Handle to the window, or NULL to stop receiving event messages.
Window message to be passed as the notification.
Value to be passed as the lParam parameter for the lMsg message.
member.returns: Returns S_OK if successful or E_INVALIDARG if the hwnd parameter is not a valid handle to a window.

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]

The IMediaEventEx interface inherits the interface, which contains methods for retrieving event notifications and for overriding the filter graph's default handling of events. IMediaEventEx adds methods that enable an application window to receive messages when events occur.
The Filter Graph Manager implements this interface.
For more information about event notification, see Event Notification in DirectShow. For a list of system-defined event notifications, see Event Notification Codes.
